[[University of West Alabama|The University of West Alabama]] currently features 13 sports teams. Men's soccer will become the 14th sport in the fall of 2012. Both the male and female athletic teams are called the '''West Alabama Tigers'''. Eleven of the thirteen teams participate in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] as a member of the [[Gulf South Conference]] East Division.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gulfsouthconference.org/about.asp?page=schools|title=Gulf South Conference-About the Gulf South Conference|publisher=''Gulf South Conference''|date=2007-01-01|accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> Men's and women's rodeo compete in the Ozark Region of the [[National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.collegerodeo.com/membership/RegionInfo.asp?Region=OZ|title=NIRA - Membership for Ozark Region|publisher=''National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association''|date=2007-01-01|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> Athletics facilities on the campus include 7,000-seat [[Tiger Stadium (West Alabama)|Tiger Stadium]], James P. Homer Fieldhouse, Pruitt Hall, Tartt Field, UWA Softball Complex, Dora Dahlberg Beard Indoor Practice Facility, Howard R. Vaughan Tennis Complex, Don C. Hines Rodeo Complex, and UWA Cross Country Facility.
Main rivalries for the program include those with the [[University of North Alabama|North Alabama Lions]] and [[Delta State University|Delta State Statesmen]]. The rivalry with North Alabama is especially heated as the two compete annually in nearly all sports. Other rivalries include those against the [[University of Alabama in Huntsville|Alabama-Huntsville Chargers]], [[Valdosta State University|Valdosta State Blazers]], [[University of West Florida|West Florida Argonauts]], and [[University of West Georgia|West Georgia Wolves]]. The Tigers had a rivalry against the [[University of Montevallo|Montevallo Falcons]] before they left the [[Gulf South Conference|GSC]] to join the [[Peach Belt Conference]].
The University's Director of Athletics is Stan Williamson. The school's official mascot is Luie the Tiger.
== Fall sports == === Football === West Alabama's football team was first fielded in 1931 when the school was known as Livingston State Teachers College. However, intercollegiate competition for all the universityâs athletics was not scheduled until seven years later. In 1938, they competed in four games against Marion Institute, [[Jacksonville State University|Jacksonville State]], Demopolis A.S, and [[Troy University|Troy State]], all of whom were local teams. LSTC finished the season 2-2.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://issuu.com/uwa_athletics/docs/uwa_football_media_guide|title=2009 UWA Football Media Guide|page=53|publisher=''UWA Athletic Department''|date=2009-08-01 |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> That year also marked the start of [[World War II]] which led to a decline in college enrollment across the United States. Therefore, LSTC fielded no athletic teams from 1942-1945. In 1944, Dr. William Wilson Hill became president of the university and instantly started recruiting students to enroll. The return of males to campus reestablished an interest in sports. After a three year hiatus, the football team returned to action under the guidance of new head coach E.G McCollum. They opened their season with the first of many future match-ups against [[Mississippi College]], which resulted in a 24-14 loss. Also, that season, LSTC renewed its rivalry with, eventual Gulf South Conference foes, Troy State and [[Delta State University|Delta State]]. The team concluded the season with a 6-3 record. Due to success of the season, McCollum resigned to pursue a bigger opportunity elsewhere. Following two dismal seasons from 1947 and 1948, LSTC made a bold move and hired former [[University of Alabama]] star Vaughn Mancha as the fourth head coach in team history. Mancha at the time was only 28 years old with no prior coaching experience. The former two-time All-American had also recently completed his first and only season in the [[National Football League|NFL]] as a member of the Boston Yanks. Under Mancha, the team experienced immediate success. In his first season, he led LSTC to one of the biggest accomplishments in school history, a 13-6 win over [[Florida State University|Florida State]]. The team also concluded the regular season 7-1-1, which at the time marked the best record in school history. The historical season earned LSTC right to play in the Paper Bowl against Jacksonville State. JSU won the hard fought defensive affair, 12-7. Up until 1952, the Tigers played home games at Livingston High School. From then on, all their home games were played at [[Tiger Stadium (West Alabama)|Tiger Stadium]], a 7,000-capacity stadium located on filled in land that was previously known as "Crawdad Creek." The stadium was built to fill the need for an on-campus stadium. Next season was once again successful as the team finished 6-3-1. However, they could not duplicate the accomplishments of the previous season. During Manchaâs third season, the team started off 2-4 and showed heavy signs of decline until putting on a strong finish to end the season 5-5. This season would mark the last in Manchaâs tenure at LSTC as he decided to take over as defensive coordinator at Florida State. Mancha departed with an 18-10-2 overall record.
The Tigers underwent a 15 year long drought without a winning season after the departure of Mancha. The teamâs most success came in 1965 when they finished 5-4. Their luck finally started to change after hiring Morris Higginbotham in 1967. Before coming to Livingston, he was one of the most successful high school coaches in Alabama, compiling a 111-27-8 record. The native of [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], earned Alabama Collegiate Conference Coach of the Year honors for the efforts of his 1968 team that featured a 9-2 mark and an appearance in the Peanut Bowl in [[Dothan, Alabama]]. Higginbotham only remained at the school for three seasons leading the Tigers to a 19-9-2 record. Higginbotham was succeeded by assistant head coach Mickey Andrews. Similar to the path of former LU head coach, Vaughn Mancha, Andrews starred in football and baseball at the University of Alabama from 1961-1964 before being hired at the university in 1967. Andrews spent three seasons guiding the UWA football team, leading the Tigers to a 24-7-2 record during his tenure. The team also won their first and only championship in school history during the 1971 season defeating [[Arkansas Tech University|Arkansas Tech]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5v0cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IJwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5660,2766987&dq=livingston+university+football&hl=en|title=Happy Tigers win big one|last=Trimm|first=Mickey|date=12 December 1971|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|page=1B|accessdate=7 March 2010}}</ref> LU's bid for a second consecutive [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] National Championship came up short to [[Carson-Newman University|Carson-Newman]] in the 1972 NAIA semi-final. Both teams battled to a 7-7 tie. However, a controversial tiebreaker ruling went in favor of Carson-Newman. In 1973, Andrews became the second LU head coach to resign and accept the defensive coordinator position at Florida State. With the next coach, once again, LU made a decision to hire a coach from within the program as they selected Andrewsâ top assistant, Jim King. King, a native of [[Adamsville, Alabama]], came to LU in 1970. In 1975, he led the Tigers to the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] playoffs with a 10-3 record. In the NCAA Quarter Finals, the team faced a tough task of taking on '''#1''' ranked [[University of North Dakota|North Dakota]]. The game was nearly cancelled due to heavy [[snow]]. Nevertheless, LU prevailed in a huge upset to move on. During the Semi-Finals, they faced a tough [[Northern Michigan University|Northern Michigan]] team on national television. Although LU jumped out to a 10-0 lead, they eventually fell short 28-26.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uwa_athletics/docs/uwa_football_media_guide|title=2009 UWA Football Media Guide|page=62|publisher=''UWA Athletic Department''|date=2009-08-01 |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> King, like several successful LU coaches before him, moved on to a new opportunity elsewhere. In only three seasons, he compiled a 29-14-1 record. Since that time, the Tigers have faced their share of good but mostly bad seasons.
The hiring of [[Bobby Wallace (American football)|Bobby Wallace]] in 2006 marked a new era within the football program. Wallaceâs first head coaching stint came in the GSC when he was the head coach at the [[University of North Alabama]] from 1988-1997. During his time at UNA, he led the Lions to three consecutive national championships from 1993-1995 as his squads finished with an overall record of 41-1 during the course of those three seasons. The 1995 team was selected as the "Best Team of the Quarter Century" in [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]]. Wallace also led UNA to Gulf South Conference Championships during the 1993-1995 seasons, while his Lions also qualified for the NCAA Division II Playoffs six times during his tenure. Over his 10 seasons at the helm, he compiled an overall mark of 82-36-1, and he also produced a total of 12 NFL players. Prior to arriving in Livingston, he had served as the head coach at [[Temple University]] since 1997. Upon hiring Wallace, many around UWA hoped he could lead the football team back to its glory days. The Wallace Era began with a great glimmer of hope as UWA recorded its first winning season in 14 years. The Tigers finished 6-5 on the season. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.waff.com/Global/story.asp?s=11431073&clienttype=printable|title=Lions No.1 Entering Regular Season Finale|date=2 November 2009|publisher=''WAFF48 News''|accessdate=7 February 2010}}</ref> UWA also ended several streaks picking up wins at [[Lambuth University|Lambuth]], against [[Southern Arkansas University|Southern Arkansas]], and at [[University of Arkansas at Monticello|Arkansas-Monticello]]. The excitement was put on hold, however, as the team finished the 2007 season with a 1-9 record and posted a 4-7 record in 2008. allace and his team put together a memorable season in 2009. The season began with three consecutive victories including a televised home win over Arkansas Tech. Unfortunately, three consecutive losses followed. A couple of wins over '''#22''' Delta State and Arkansas-Monticello put UWA right back in the thick of the playoff race, but a loss to [[University of West Georgia|West Georgia]] the following week nearly derailed their hopes. During the season finale, UWA was locked in a battle for their playoff lives against longtime rival and Wallaceâs former team, North Alabama. At the time, UNA was ranked '''#1''' in all the Division II polls. Through a fearless and courageous effort, UWA sent the game to [[overtime (sports)|overtime]] after losing the lead they held throughout the game. After four overtimes, it appeared UNA was set to claim the victory until a forced fumble gave UWA the ball. From that, they took advantage and kicked the game winning field goal. It was the first win for the Tigers at [[Braly Municipal Stadium]] in [[Florence, Alabama|Florence]] since the 1987 season. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gulfsouthconference.org/news.asp?sport=&id=388970|title=2009 GSC Football Week In Review, Nov. 9|date=9 November 2009|publisher=''Gulf South Conference''|accessdate=7 February 2010}}</ref> The NCAA rewarded UWA's efforts with a berth in the [[2009 NCAA Division II National Football Championship playoffs|NCAA Division II playoffs]]. In the first round, the Tigers upset '''#20''' Albany State 24-22 on the road. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ncaa.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/111409aaf.html=en|title=West Alabama Edges Albany State|date=14 November 2009|publisher=NCAA.com|accessdate=6 February 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> After falling behind early against '''#10''' Carson-Newman, the Tigers mounted a rally before falling short 59-41. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ncaa.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/112109aau.htmlen|title=No. 10 Carson-Newman Holds Off West Alabama|date=21 November 2009|publisher=NCAA.com|accessdate=6 February 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The Tigers gathered an 8-5 record, the most wins since 1975, and had eight All-GSC honors. UWA posted a 5-1 record at Tiger Stadium, the best since 1985, and tallied the most wins over GSC opponents since 1981 with six.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uwaathletics.com/news/2009/11/30/FB_1130094925.aspx?path=football|title=Five Named to Daktronics All-Super Region 2 Team|publisher=''UWA Athletic Department''|date=2009-11-30|accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> They received their first two rankings in school history at the end of the season. The [[American Football Coaches Association|AFCA]] placed them '''#21''', while the [http://www.d2football.com/ D2Football.com] poll placed them higher two spots at '''#19'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afca.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=9300&ATCLID=204848389 |title=Northwest Missouri State Ends Season at No. 1 Division II Poll|publisher=''American Football Coaches Association''|date=2009-12-14 |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.d2football.com/top25poll/11/|title=2009 D2Football.com Top 25 Media Poll - Final Poll|publisher=''D2Football.com''|date=2010-01-25|accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
UWA entered the 2010 season ranked 12th nationally by [[USA Today]]. The team was also ranked 23rd in the Lindyâs Preseason Top 25 poll and 24th in the Sporting News Preseason Top 25 poll.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulfsouthconference.org/news.asp?action=form&recordID=459107&sport=FOOTBALL|title=GSC Football in National Pre-Season Publications|publisher=''Gulf South Conference''|date=2010-07-23|accessdate=2010-08-07}}</ref> The UWA football team recorded its highest pre-season ranking since 1976 as the Tigers were selected second by the head coaches of the 2010 Gulf South Conference in the GSC Pre-Season Poll. The Red and White previously entered as the top ranked team in 1976 and 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulfsouthconference.org/news.asp?action=form&recordID=473970&sport=FOOTBALL |title=2010 GSC Football Pre-Season Release|publisher=''Gulf South Conference''|date=2010-08-03|accessdate=2010-08-07}}</ref> West Alabama opened the season on August 28 against NAIA member [[Shorter University|Shorter]] in nearby [[Demopolis, Alabama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.demopolistimes.com/2010/01/19/uwa-to-play-season-opener-in-demopolis/|title=UWA to play season opener in Demopolis|publisher=''Demopolis Times''|date=2010-01-19|accessdate=2010-08-07}}</ref> Tiger Stadium saw a major renovation as a synthetic surface was recently installed. The Tigers played their first contest on the new surface on September 18 against Lambuth but were narrowly defeated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20100728/NEWS/100729569/1015?p=1&tc=pg |title=UWA to play on synthetic surface|publisher=''Tuscaloosa Times''|date=2010-07-28|accessdate=2010-08-07}}</ref> UWA opened Gulf South Conference play with a home win over West Georgia but fell short to Delta State on the road. After a 3-2 start, the Tigers reeled off three consecutive wins including a last-second Homecoming triumph over [[Henderson State University|Henderson State]]. It appeared the game had ended, but officials put a second back on the clock. Quarterback Deon Williams connected to wide receiver Gerald Worsham in the back of the endzone for the game-winner.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20101017/NEWS/101019670|title=UWA pulls off miracle with last-second score |last=Carroll|first=Andrew|date=17 October 2010|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> The team dropped back-to-back heartbreakers the following two weeks before returning home to face Valdosta State in the season finale. The day before the contest, Bobby Wallace announced to his players that he would be stepping down as head coach upon the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20101111/NEWS/101119976|title=UWAâs Wallace retiring|last=Carroll|first=Andrew|date=11 November 2010|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> After falling behind and trailing at the half, the Tigers upset the '''#7''' ranked Blazers to give Wallace a victory in his final game. The team notched its second win ever against Valdosta State and picked up their first win in the series since 1985. UWA finished the season 7-4 to earn consecutive winning seasons for the first time since 1991 and 1992.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.demopolistimes.com/2010/11/12/uwa-sends-wallace-out-with-a-w/|title=UWA sends Wallace out with a âWâ|last=Cannon|first=Jason|date=12 November 2010|publisher=''Demopolis Times''|accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> Deon Williams was recognized as one of 24 candidates for the Harlon Hill Trophy, the [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] equivalent to [[NCAA Division I|Division I]]'s [[Heisman Trophy]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20101113/NEWS/101119898?tc=ar|title=Williams a Harlon Hill Trophy candidate |date=13 November 2010|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> Offensive coordinator [[Will Hall (American football)|Will Hall]] was named Bobby Wallace's successor a week after the season concluded.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20101117/NEWS/101119690?tc=ar|title=Will Hall to take over West Alabama football program|last=Carroll|first=Andrew|date=17 November 2010|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref> Bobby Wallace was inducted into the Division II Hall of Fame in December to close out a storied career.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesdaily.com/article/20101218/SPORTS110/101219811?Title=Wallace-8217-s-Hall-of-Fame-homecoming|title=Wallaceâs Hall of Fame homecoming|last=App|first=Bryan|date=18 December 2010|publisher=''Times Daily''|accessdate=30 May 2011}}</ref>
=== Volleyball === The first known volleyball team for the University of West Alabama came in 1979. UWA struggled throughout the 1980s and early part of the 1990s. At this time, only season schedules beginning in 1994 are available. Under the direction of head coach Pam Gailbreath, the team won 9 games that year. The following year, UWA improved on its previous season finishing at 17-18. In 1996, the Tigers reached an all-time high going 32-14 to set a school record for wins. The next four seasons proved difficult for the Tigers as they could not get over the .500 point. Then, in 2001, UWA won 23 games to finish with a .575 winning percentage. They improved even more in 2002 when they went 25-13.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uwa_athletics/docs/2009_media_guide|title=2009 UWA Volleyball Media Guide|pages=35â36|publisher=''UWA Athletic Department''|date=2009-08-01|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref>
After another cold spell through 2006, the 2007 season brought highlights setting the tone for years to come. UWA started the campaign 18-0 and was the only [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] undefeated team in [[United States of America|America]]. For their efforts, the [[American Volleyball Coaches Association|AVCA]] placed them '''#25''', the first ranking in the program's history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulfsouthconference.org/news.asp?sport=Volleyball&id=239008|title=West Alabama Volleyball Ranked For The First Time In School History|publisher=''Gulf South Conference''|date=2007-10-01 |accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> A sweep over [[Albany State University|Albany State]] broke the school record for most consecutive wins.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20070930/NEWS/71001018|title=UWA volleyball team sweeps Albany State|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|date=2007-09-30|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> They went on to finish the season 27-6 in head coach Ron Arenz's final year. UWA recorded 8 conference wins, the most for the team since 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20071104/NEWS/71104010|title=UWA volleyball team gets 3-1 win|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|date=2007-11-04|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> Although the season ended in the opening round of the GSC Tournament, the Tigers broke several school records throughout the season. In 2008, UWA continued their winning ways and achieved a 22-11 record. However, the Tigers learned they would be losing another head coach.
Assistant coach Tabitha Turner was promoted to head coach for 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uwaathletics.com/coaches.aspx?rc=8&path=wvball|title=2009 Women's Volleyball Coaching Staff|publisher=''UWA Athletic Department''|date=2009-06-01|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> UWA was picked to finish third in the annual preseason poll.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20090806/NEWS/908059921|title=UWA volleyball team picked third in GSC East|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|date=2009-08-06|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> After starting the season slow through 14 games, the Tigers reeled off a 16-match winning streak pushing their record to 25-5 and 5-0 in the GSC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20091022/NEWS/910219922|title=Turner enjoying new duties as UWA coach|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|date=2009-10-22|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> It was the third consecutive season in which UWA had won at least 20 matches. The team won the GSC East Division crown with a win at [[Valdosta State University|Valdosta State]] to close out regular season play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uwaathletics.com/news/2009/11/30/WVB_1130095714.aspx?path=wvball|title=UWA Claims GSC East Division Championship With 3-1 Win Over Valdosta State|publisher=''UWA Athletic Department''|date=2009-11-07|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref><!--The reference says 11/30/2009, but this was added when the new UWA website debuted. Therefore, the date is not valid, and the original story came from 11/07/2009.--> At the GSC Tournament, the Tigers fought back from a 2-1 deficit to top [[Arkansas Tech University|Arkansas Tech]] and advance to the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20091114/NEWS/911149997?tc=ar|title=UWA volleyball advances to semifinals|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|date=2009-11-14|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> In the semi-finals, the team blanked [[Harding University|Harding]] in a convincing sweep on their home court. A bid for the school's first GSC Championship ended in heartbreak to [[University of West Florida|West Florida]]. UWA finished the season 30-8 and 8-2 in GSC play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20091115/NEWS/911149939?tc=ar|title=UWA volleyball falls in championship game|publisher=''Tuscaloosa News''|date=2009-11-15|accessdate=2010-02-07}}</ref> After the season, Tabitha Turner was selected by the [[American Volleyball Coaches Association|AVCA]] Thirty Under 30 list for 2010. Created in 2009, the award honors the top 30 at all volleyball levels. Instrumental in her first season at the helm and first as a head coach, Turner was also named Co-Coach of the Year in the East Division.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uwaathletics.com/news/2010/2/8/WVB_0208104734.aspx|title=UWA's Tabitha Turner Named To AVCA's Thirty Under 30 List|publisher=''UWA Athletic Department''|date=2010-01-01|accessdate=2010-02-08}}</ref> The 2010 season was a rebuilding year for the Tigers as the squad finished with a 10-21 overall record.
